site_data.title: Site Data
site_data.description: Improve Soil ID results by entering some data for this site using the helpful guides along the way.

location_score_info.p1: Location score is based solely on soil maps and the site’s location. This does not take into account data that has been entered by users at the site.
location_score_info.p2: LandPKS bases soil matches on soil maps created by the USDA NRCS. Traditional soil maps don’t predict a single soil for each location; they are organized into “soil map units” that each contain multiple possible soils. Each possible soil in a map unit is estimated to cover a certain percentage of the unit.
location_score_info.p3: The <bold>location score</bold> for a soil match is based on the percentage of the map unit that the soil covers. It is then reduced by a value proportional to the distance of the map unit from the site. In other words, soils in the site’s map unit generally receive a higher location score than soils in a neighboring map unit. Similarly, soils that make up a larger percentage of the map unit receive a higher location score than soils that make up a smaller percentage of the map unit.

soil_properties_score_info.p1: Soil Properties Score reflects the similarity between the soil match and the data entered for this site.
soil_properties_score_info.p2: A higher Soil Properties Score means that the user-entered data is similar to the soil match. A low score means the two are less similar, and it is less likely for this match to be the correct soil ID for the site.
soil_properties_score_info.p3: The more data entered for a site, the more reliable the Soil Properties Score will be.

texture.title: Soil Texture
texture.label: Texture

info.title: Soil Texture
info.description:
Soil is made up of particles of different sizes. Once you remove all large particles (anything over $t(soil.texture.info.description_diameter,{"context":"{{units}}"}) in diameter), what is left is a mixture of sand, silt, and clay.

<bold>Soil texture</bold> is determined by the percent of sand, silt, and clay in the soil. Changes in this ratio can have large impacts on the potential of the soil.

Soil texture determines many important characteristics of your land, including:

<bullets />
Knowing the soil texture also helps you more accurately identify your soil.
info.point1: How much water the soil can hold
info.point2: How quickly water can be absorbed into and percolate through the soil
info.point3: How easily soil erodes when exposed to wind or water
info.point4: How soil responds to management activities (for example, compaction from tillage operations)

guide.title: Texture Guide
guide.ball_help: Does the soil form a ball?
guide.ribbon_help: Does the soil form a ribbon?
guide.prepare_details_1: Get a soil sample of at least a few handfuls.
guide.prepare_details_2: Remove all rock fragments larger than 2mm. Use a sieve if you have one.
guide.wet_details_1: Pick up a handful of soil the size of a golf ball (≈25 g).
guide.wet_details_2: Use a spray bottle to slowly apply water to the sample.
guide.wet_details_3: Work the water uniformly into the soil with your hands.
guide.wet_details_4: The soil should be thoroughly damp, but not glistening, with a texture like putty. If the soil is too wet, add more dry soil from your sample.
guide.wet_details_5: Avoid working the soil with your hands for longer than 2 minutes. If you go beyond 2 minutes, discard the soil and start with a new sample.
guide.ball_details_1: Roll the soil in your hands to see if it forms a ball.
guide.ball_details_2: If it crumbles when you apply slight pressure to roll it, the soil does not form a ball.
guide.ribbon_details_1: Grip the soil with your fingers (not your thumb).
guide.ribbon_details_2: Use the inside of your thumb knuckle (the flat part) to push the soil upwards over the edge of your index finger. Do not use the tip of your thumb to press the soil.
guide.ribbon_details_3: The ribbon should be parallel to the floor, not pointing upward or downwards.
guide.ribbon_details_4: If the soil crumbles instead of holding together when you press to form a ribbon, then it does not form a ribbon.
guide.ribbon_details_5: Let the ribbon fall naturally due to gravity. Measure the length of the segment, ignoring ragged edges.
guide.grittyness_details_1: <0>Gritty</0> means you can feel individual grains in the soil.
guide.grittyness_details_2: <0>Smooth</0> means that the wetted soil is slippery or soapy in feel.
guide.grittyness_details_3: <0>Not gritty or smooth</0> means that neither of those two textures dominates. You may still feel some sand grains or some soapiness, but the feel of the soil is not predominantly one or the other.

texture.guide_intro: Don’t know your soil texture? Use the step-by-step guide.

info.title: Rock Fragment Volume
info.description:
Rock fragment volume is a measurement of how much of the soil volume is taken up by rocks, which is defined as anything larger than $t(soil.texture.fragment.info.description_diameter,{"context":"{{units}}"}) in diameter.

This can be estimated visually by comparing the volume of the soil before and after removing the rocks, as well as by comparing the volume of rocks removed to the volume of the remaining soil.

Alternatively, for a more precise measurement, you can place the rocks from the sample in a bucket with a known volume of water and measure the change in volume. Then divide that volume by the volume of the original soil sample to get a percentage.

info.p1: Soil color can tell you a lot about soil, including:
info.bullet2: How much organic matter is present
info.p2: Soil color can be measured using a Munsell book or spectrometer.
info.p3: In this app, you can also take a photo with a reference card like a Post-it Note to determine your soil color.

step1.title: 1. Gather Post-it Notes.
step1.content: To ensure accurate color analysis you must use 3M Canary Yellow Post-it Notes for your reference card, with these guidelines:

bullets.2: Stack at least 3 Post-it Notes on top of each other.
bullets.3: Make sure each Post-it note lays flat, isn’t written on, and isn’t dirty.
bullets.4: Make sure each Post-it note isn’t degraded by sunlight, as considerable variation can exist depending on sun exposure.
bullets.5: Store Post-it notes in dark envelopes to avoid sun exposure.

step2.title: 2. Prepare Soil Sample.
step2.content:
Use dry soil whenever possible. The app does have a way to indicate if your soil is wet, but dry soil color estimates are more accurate.

If your soil layer has multiple colors (i.e. mottles, redoximorphic features, or carbonates), isolate the dominant matrix color from the pile.

Run soil through a $t(soil.color.guide.step2.content_size,{"context":"{{units}}"}) sieve to create a pile of homogenous soil, or use your hands to pick out anything larger than $t(soil.color.guide.step2.content_size,{"context":"{{units}}"}).

Flatten the pile of soil to minimize shadows within the soil sample.

step3.title: 3. Prepare lighting.
step3.content:
The soil color photo needs to be taken in even lighting conditions and shaded from direct sun.

Try to have an overhead light source rather than side lighting.

step4.title: 4. Place reference card next to soil.
step4.content: Place the Post-it note next to the prepared soil sample, in the proper lighting conditions.

step5.title: 5. Compose photo.
step5.content: Place the camera as close to the soil and Post-It note as you can without creating shadows or blurriness.

step6.title: 6. Ready to take the photo?
step6.content: If you’ve followed the instructions above, you’re ready! You can take a photo with your device’s camera, or go back to upload a photo.

info.title: Slope
info.description:
Describe the characteristics of the slope of the land on which the site is located.

Instructions on how to collect each data input are available by tapping on the input name.

Slope is important in identifying the soil. It also helps determine the soil’s erosion potential, ability to hold water, and more.

steepness.description: Enter steepness manually, using the slope meter, or selecting from the images below.

info.title: How to use Slope Meter
info.description:
Stand facing the site from at least $t(slope.steepness.info.description_distance, {"context": "{{units}}"}) away.

Identify the direction of the predominant slope at the site.

Stand so that you can see the ridge or silhouette of that predominant slope (although you may need to get close to the ground to see it.)

The direction you are facing should be perpendicular to the direction of the slope. If you hold your arms out to your sides, the line they make should be parallel to the direction of the slope.

Position your phone so that the solid white line is lined up with the land’s slope; try to place the white line along the slope’s edge. You may need to crouch down if the silhouette of the slope is not easy to see while standing.

<bold>Alternate Method</bold>: If the land shape is not too curved or bumpy, you can place a yard stick on the ground at the site and then align your phone on the stick to get the angle of the slope.

info.title: Slope Shape
info.description:
Slope shape refers to the way the land curves in the area surrounding your site point.

Slope shape is determined in two directions: <bold>downslope</bold> and <bold>cross-slope</bold>.

First, determine the primary direction of the slope at the site. Ignore small bumps or ditches; look about $t(slope.shape.info.description_distance, {"context": "{{units}}"}) in all directions.

If it rained, in which general direction would water flow downhill? This is called the <bold>downslope</bold> direction.

The cross-slope direction can be found by looking at a right angle (90 degrees) from the downslope direction.

If you walk away from the site while staying at the same elevation, this is the <bold>cross-slope</bold> direction.

Second, determine the shape of the slope for each direction.

<bold>Concave</bold> means that the land slopes increasingly upward as you move away from your point along the cross slope or downslope. For example, the downslope is often concave at the foot of a hill as it changes from a steep slope to a more shallow one.

<bold>Convex</bold> means that the land slopes increasingly downward as you move away from your point along a particular direction. For example, the downslope is often convex at the top of a hill as it changes from a shallow slope to a steeper one.

<bold>Linear</bold> means the slope is consistent along the entirety of a particular direction. It does not necessarily mean the land is flat; it just means that the slope does not change.
